Why has no one commented that teleportation means your DEATH. Every time I encounter this, it seems the topic just zooms past the 'death' part to get to the 'neat' stuff. The problem is still real. If you deconstruct your atoms and move, copy, or clone them elsewhere... ~YOU~ are dead. A clone, that is NOT you (but thinks it IS you) has been created. You don't NOTICE it because you are killed at the same time the clone is made...YOU have died when your body is taken apart. YOUR future is OVER when you 'teleport' and a clone of you starts living. You do not stop living for a second, then continue living again in the NEW location and new body. That is ...unbelievable. Your consciousness is a result of all your neurons interacting inside your body. (That's what consciousness is: your PHYSICAL neurons) You can't 'transfer' consciousness. It is the physical makeup of your brain. Deconstruction ENDS consciousness. You are ONLY making a clone. How is this not understood?

Think about it this way. You go into the teleporter and it 'teleports' (makes a clone of) you across the room, but doesn't 'deconstruct' you yet. (It just... waits for a second or two) You SEE yourself appear on the other side of the room, but YOU are still in the teleporter. You see the CLONE of you walking off, thinking IT is you... and THEN the teleporter machine you are standing in KILLS- er... deconstructs you. Ask yourself. Does your consciousness NOW suddenly fly over to the clone's body and ERASE the clone's consciousness so YOU can now control it? Does your consciousness exist in BOTH locations at once? Does the EXACT replica clone of you (with the same brain and neurons as you) somehow just stay an empty shell, a dead body, until your consciousness 'flies' over to it? Has anyone even bothered to THINK about how silly this all is?

Using the cat and fleas you made this even more entangled (pun intended. I mean "more complicated").
The Schroedinger's cat is not meant to be an explanation of quantum superposition. Schroedinger himself constructed the thought experiment with the cat to demonstrate that the quantum states of atoms may have macroscopical implications like this, and that is "not real", he and Einstein agreed that the cat is either dead or alive, independently of whether it is observed or not.
The cat being dead or alive is not just one one state. To transmit the cat, you would have to transmit each of its atoms (or even subatomic particles) independently.

Also, in the end you basically just said that the cat was not teleported, just the information how the cat looks... and the "pile of particles that make a cat" was already there... That is a huge not-a-teleportation, if you need the particles already there. Also, how would you assemble them? Let's say you have a pile of hydrogen atoms, pile of oxygen atoms, carbon atoms, etc (and basically every element that the cat happens to have inside it) (or you have just protons, electrons, neutrons, and make smash them together to make the needed atoms? that's not easy in inself...)... You set the quantum state of each of the atoms... and then what? How would you make a cat out of them?

Okay, mind blown.

After doing the Brilliant.org course on quantum computing and rewatching this video for the 3rd time (pausing liberally so it took over an hour), I finally start to understand this.

I think one confusing part of the video is that by framing it as a "sneaky way of measuring the box", it portrays it as a harmless measurement when in fact, it's a quantum operation that scrambles the contents of the box. Also, there's the disappointment when you find out that quantum teleportation doesn't allow faster-than-light communication, and you actually need to transmit the measurements using traditional channels to reconstruct the cat on the other end.

As soon as you interact with the particle (or measure it) entanglement is broken, so you can't modify the remote particle's properties.

That is actually an example of the uncertainty principle and relativity.

A cat and two fleas walk into a bar. The bartender, who is the creator of minutephysics, decides to send one flea to the moon to try and teleport the cat to the moon while trying to make a 14 minute video at the same time while managing to do all that within microseconds. But wait! This is Schrodinger's cat, which means that by simply looking at the cat minutephysics has destroyed it. Trying to fix his mistake, he keeps the two entangled flies in a jar, keeping them entangled for as long as possible while he speed-watches his previous videos about time travel. He builds a time machine, and accidentally kills his grandfather. Now what to do? He watches his video on the Grandfather's paradox to resolve the situation, but while he was doing so 3blue1brown captured him and forced him to work in the attic to upload a video on Feynman's Lost Lecture, all the while stealing the time machine to do things on his own. Eventually minutephysics escaped but he has very little time before the fleas become useless. So he tries to learn relativity to slow down time, but since he is constant pressure to upload videos he had to upload an entire series. With his now-useless cat in his hand and very little fuel in his rocket, he needs to find a way to get energy from a cat, which he researches, finding that Norway goes through 150 billion cats a year. He patents a new solution and throws the cat in a black hole. He also throws the fleas, in, too, since they have long since decohered and lost their special entanglement properties. Arriving back to earth with seconds of fuel to spare, he ditches the idea of doing it in real life and makes this absolutely wonderful video.

Interesting from a theoretical standpoint, but IMO you're glossing over two things:
1) You have the known quantum states of all these particles, but don't you still have to physically arrange those particles very precisely (and quickly; i.e., before any of their quantum states change)?
2) Even solving that problem, it is a fact not yet in evidence that precisely duplicating a cat's molecular configuration, and the quantum states of all the particles involved, makes the result the "same" cat. Physics might be able to confirm (again in theory) that the molecular and quantum configurations are identical, but whether that constitutes being the same cat is a question for your sister channel, minutephilosophy. :-)

Let me briefly explain spin up and spin down. First, throw out everything you've been taught about electrons being in an eliptical or circular obit around the nucleus. It's just a theory, but electrons are speculated to be moving on wavelengths, some on the same, some on different. Those different wavelengths are called principle energy levels or shells. I could dive into the specifics of what a shell is, but for spin up spin down, it's only necessary to know that inside shells are subshells, which have orbitals inside. An orbital can hold two electrons, but they must face away from each other to fit because they are both negatively charged (think shoes in a shoebox). But there is no up and down because that relies on perspective, and thus an electron in an orbital is both up and down. A superposition.

You can't just teleport someone by reassembling an exact copy when we don't even understand how consciousness works. If the original were to be disassembled and then reassembled at another point, the consciousness would die with the original template. Although this type of teleportation COULD result in an exact copy, possibly with the same memories, it would not contain the consciousness of the original.

Assuming that somehow we achieve the feat of disassembly/reassembly teleportation, based on this information there is no way we could even determine if the consciousness of the template traveled with the information. Since the copy would share the same mind, there's no way to determine whether or not the consciousness made it through, as it would have no way to determine that it hadn't existed beforehand. The copy would believe it was the original.

The only way to fully determine the outcome is whether or not we will even have ye ability to replicate life, which at the moment seems pretty far off.

In my opinion, the only feasible and nonlethal form of teleportation that may some day be a reality is the manipulation of spacetime to instantaneously shift the location of an object or organism.

Hey if and when we can teleport intelligent animals, I think you could test the mind-body problem. To most scientists this is not a problem because an assumption of science is that the universe is entirely materialistic, with no spiritual or metaphysical elements such as a separate conscious. This position is called Materialism. (Or materialistic monism) On the other hand, many believe in the spiritual, metaphysical and a consciousness separate from the physical body, whether it be called the mind, spirit or soul. This position is called dualism.
Test it with teleportation. According to Dualism, a teleported being may have all particles in the right place but shouldn't be able to survive or function without its 'spirit' and according to Materialism a being should be able to survive teleportation with its consciousness intact.
For practical purposes you could do a pre- and post-teleport maze navigation test to see if memory has been disturbed.

As I currently understand it, the quantum states of atoms are not at all relevant to who you are. Even if you switch the quantum state of every single atom in your body, you would still be "the same person", as long as you avoid some highly excited states and do not change the chemical bonds. As it stands at the moment, quantum teleportation (QT) does not relate to the positions of or chemical bonds between atoms. Maybe at a later moment it will stand for something fundamentally more. But currently QT relates to very close to 0% of the actual teleportation problem, i.e., to transporting the physical positions of groups of particles. You would have to have all the same molecules arranged in the correct order at the receiving end before you could transfer the quantum state.

So, as I understand it, QT is a great name choice that suggests something fundamentally different than what it actually is. Great name for funding and PR, but mainly by creating confusion.

So! Where is the problem in cloning a clone? If looking at the state of a particle can change the state of the particle, then looking at every position of every particle in your body would turn you into a pile of goo. But, you'd have the position of every particle and if you could give another pile of goo all of those particle states, you'd have a clone. This is fine, and makes plenty of sense. But, what if you stored that state of each particle in a computer?

There is nothing in Quantum Mechanics that says you cannot remember the state of a particle after looking at it. So, while you view and log the position of each individual particle, you can now create a clone whenever you feel like it. Including 5 seconds after creating the first one. Now you can create a Clone Army through particle physics, instead of trying to artificially age an army, one "clone" at a time. Seems very useful for The Empire.

All jokes aside. I answered my own question while asking my question. When you create the first clone, all of its particles are now changing. If you look at all of its particles to clone it, then the first clone will turn into a pile of goo. You aren't "cloning a clone", you are still cloning the first (now a pile of goo). At that point, you are just creating the original you over and over. Still great for a Clone Army, but not so great for throwing a wrench into Quantum teleportation.

Maybe I'm just an ignoramus spitballing here, but... I thought the experiments so far involved pairs of entangled particles, one remains at the source location and one is moved to the destination location. And when the quantum state of the source changes, that change is "teleported" to the entangled partner particle at the destination. If that's the case, then they're only teleporting data, not particles. And so, let's say you have accumulated the same number of particles present in the flea, entangled each one with a particle in the flea, and moved that container of particles a meter away. Now you can observe the quantum state of those particles in the container to know if the quantum state of any of the flea's particles have changed, knowing that the quantum state of any particle in the flea would be teleported and thus change the quantum state of its entangled partner. You still don't have a flea in the container and no particles were actually teleported. You haven't actually assembled a flea and you still have to transport those partner particles by some traditional means.

I can see applications in computer science where we send particles to a destination that contain no information and then change their state at the quantum level where it would teleport presumably immune to interception.

Clever argumentation.
But as with all teleportation advocates you overlook one thing: the Heissenbergs Uncertainty!
If you could teleport any object using whatever method, the object either would arrive on the intended spot, or it would arrive with an intended momentum.
Both simultaneously can not be achieved, due to the Uncertainty princyple.
So if you manage to teleport your cat to the moon, it either a) will arrive as a diffuse cloud of particles or b) either slam to the moon or fly off into space!
Teleporting any macroscopic object is, in this sense, in my eyes, Impossible!

0:55 I still have a problem with this. The original was destroyed because it would be inhumane and/or just not possible to let the original live. But the teleported subject it a clone. This method of teleportation is still effectively "suicide and copy". There is difference between cloning and being the only one. In either case, you are being copied from an original. But the difference is if the original survives to be copied again.

Trying to rationalize that the copy is the original is throwing Star Trek fans a bone. I'm a Trekker myself and I think Bones McCoy was absolutely RIGHT to hate the Transporter Device. But the fact that Star Trek itself actually addresses this with the disease known as "Transporter Psychosis". While they say in the show "we have no idea what causes it" The truth is brutally clear. These are people who realize and understand they are NOT the original. The fact that Bones McCoy never really lets go of his disdain for the TD, even in very old age, is a major clue that he may have a form of "Reconciled Transporter Psychosis", such that he and his subsequent copies know they are copies and just carry on, as opposed to the usual "Transporter Psychosis Denial" in which the subject just refuses to acknowledge that they are the copy to the point that all facts point to it are simply ignored and "we don't know what causes it".

In a civilization that puts massive emphasis on finding the truth and answers to problems, that their skills and science have advanced so far that they can literally "Mary Sue" almost anything we today can think of, it makes no sense that this future civilization can not deduce what Transporter Psychosis is, why it is, and if there is anything at all they can do about it. Hint: STOP using the transporter device to transport living beings. Start using shuttles more often or only to transport people.

"No cloning implies that the teleported one is unequivocally the real one" That's too much of a logic leap. A process that requires to damage the original to create a good copy doesn't mean that the copy is now the original.

Teleportation will always be a method of suicide with limited consequences, period. From your perspective, you die. From everyone else's, you live. The fact that the clone is the exact copy at a quantum level is irrelevant.

Edit: Later in the video about the word CAT: "I mean, it's obvious, only one of them is a cat". Again, NO. This is confirmation biais at its finest. Not because you destroyed the original and managed to construct a good copy, and that the good copy is the only thing remaining, means that the original has been teleported. There is zero logical connexion here.

What you have is a one-time use construction machine, which ability is to build stuff out of the raw materials. Only once. Using a "copy" (the original) as a one-time use blueprint.

There is something that deeply bothers me about this.

You claim that if I teleported myself, the one that is at the destination would be 100% me, without a doubt, just because the "original" me doesn't exist anymore?

I disagree.

Yes, I know that to an external observer, or to any instrument, and even to the clone itself, it would seem like they were exactly the same person as before, and they would not be able to tell the difference, but, if the original remained alive (I know you said it's impossible) he would think that the cloned version is a separate entity, and he would be right. They don't share the same consciousness, the same "point of view".

You say that it's impossible to make a perfect copy of an object without destroying its atomic composition by "jumbling" it completely, and that's true, but only if you intend to make an atomically perfect copy of the object. That might or might not be strictly necessary to make a "good enough" clone of the original.

Its not teleportation, The only reason they call it teleportation is to generate hype.

Its not faster than light(the information has to be transmitted, and then applied). Its not the same particles or entangled ones (They reconfigure the other particles at the destination to match the ones that they measured.). And correct me if I'm wrong here, but It doesn't seem possible in anyway to recover the arrangement of particles that you have measured either, as their local interactions would break the entanglement before fully reassembling the object. They can recover the spin state, but not arrangement(No cat, just particles withe the same state as a now dead cat.)


It is a very clever way to recover the probability state of particles after you have measured them. Its surprising that they can do it, since you can never measure the exact probability state in QM.

This is not teleportation... This is just probability. If you want teleportation, you must collapse the wave function in a specific way, to ensure the state gets to the other side. I doubt that we could do teleportation this way. BUT! We can entangle just two, or better, four atoms in pairs, and we can teleport just information (binary code), instantly, across whatever distance. This will revolutionize space communication. Imagine ultra-high-speed Internet across the entire Solar System, or even across different solar systems. Once you achieve that... you could just scan an object or person and build an exact same replica on the other side. Provided that you have all the materials to build it there. No need for the entire thing to be entangled. But I doubt anyone would offer to try this, knowing it's certain death. But with objects there would be no such problems. If we'll send Generation Spaceships across the Universe, this will be a way to stay up to date with the technology on Earth. Assuring that things don't diverge. At least technologically. Biologically they will certainly do.

@0:50 shitty dodge of philosophical question.
No-cloning tells us you can't have PERFECT copy of unknonw q-state. But hypothetical "human teleporter" device doesn't require to send over exact full Q state of a human.

You don't even need to bother with quantum stuff, if scanner is good enough to collect particles positioning information (orbitals for electrons). You still send information only, not components of a body, but you don't need to send exact quantum dump. A reconstructed body would still be adequate enough facsimile of the original.

There's no scientific data to suggest a person's "selfness" or consciousnesses is in anyway directly reliant on quantum physics. So, you don't need to transmit quantum states to transmit self-awareness, plain chemistry will take care of it.

Thus, it is very possible to make a duplicate of a person, sending only information, not particles themselves, as long as you are willing to discard some irrelevant data. And quantum state of all the entangled particles in our body is, for all we know, irrelevant. It could be reconstructed from a blank state on the receiving end.

Does it fail to exist during the time that it takes for the moon observer to read the signal and perform the operation on the moon flea to turn it into a cat? Or is the Earth cat still existent on the Earth until the moon observer actually performs the flea transformation operation, at which point it'd spontaneously disassemble itself into a pile of particles?

If the cat does stop existing as soon as you beam the information up, could you just send the signal over and then just wait for years, with the information to reconstruct the cat available without actually doing so (assuming we can keep the entanglement on both ends)? We'd then have a sort of eternal life machine (or, I guess, a forward-only time machine), since we can revive the cat to its still-youthful state even years later.

That leads into the question, what would happen if you do all this and send over the information about the cat - but before you can reconstruct the cat, the entanglement fails? On the Earth, that means you'd have a pile of particles, right? But on the moon, you'd have a flea that's now entangled with the moon environment instead of just the Earth flea. The cat's information is still encoded somehow in the moon flea + decoding operation information, but doing the operation straight-up would not recreate the cat because of this extra entanglement. So that'd make this a pretty horrific murder device, just zapping bodies away and leaving behind meaningless piles of particles.
